Headline: Fractional COO & AIâ€‘atâ€‘Scale Transformation Partner | $10M+ Value Creator | Ops + CX + Automation | Exâ€‘Nykaa, Paytm, Chegg | LinkedIn Top Voice | Duke AI PM | IIM-A Leadership
Comment:
Most leaders view discounting as a revenue lever, but it's actually a 'retention' liability. You're training a cohort with low CLV. In my experience, the real cost is the ~70% of discount-driven customers marketers struggle to retain post-sale. The focus must shift from quarterly sales spikes to LTV. 

What's the most effective non-price incentive you've seen work? Avik Ashar

Headline: Strategy & IR @ Shaya Polymers | Investments | CA | CFA L-2 Passed
Comment: Completely agree Avik Ashar. Dropping prices is always the easiest lever to pull. But once you go down that path, itâ€™s incredibly hard to climb back up. Iâ€™ve seen many founders underestimate how quickly they can lose pricing power once customers get used to discounts.

Headline: Indiaâ€™s First Marketing Psychology Specialist ğŸ§  â€¢ Founder - The Buyerâ€™s Mindâ„¢ â€¢ Turning Consumer Behavior Into Predictable Growth â€¢ Author
Comment:
Avik Ashar, more than laziness, it's the lack of real business and marketing skills, and an inability to understand the buyer's mind and psychology.
Â 
Instead of helping customers see the value of the product, they are happy to diminish the worth of their product and brand.
Â 
Let me share the exact words of one of the founders I recently encountered. He said, "I want only rich and premium people to buy our product, it should have a luxury vibe........ and yes, let's give a 30% discount offer too."
Â 
The pandemic of discounting has the 3rd most common excuse, "Indians are price sensitive, they don't buy without discounts."
Â 
I have also seen discounts significantly impact returns and cancellations. When these "founders" rely on discounts as a core strategy due to desperation and FOMO, they are left questioning why their brand lacks trust and respect.

Vanshikaa Oberoi, the emoji needs to be made public ğŸ¤£ .

Headline: CEO, Silverpot Tea
Comment: Discounts is a downward spiral 99% companies should avoid. Building Silverpot Tea I've been really solid on the idea that we never give discounts (including festive seasons). In fact we actively explore ways in which we can increase the prices without meaningfully hurting demand

Headline: Co-Founder & CTO | Building Devize â€” The Business OS for Modern Enterprises
Comment: Avik Ashar Perfectly put â€” discounting feels like growth until it becomes addiction. ğŸ’¸ Youâ€™re not just moving inventory, youâ€™re reshaping perception. Smart brands build loyalty with value and experience, not flash sales and slashed prices.

Headline: Founder | Solving Growth Challenges with Strategy, Tech & a Bit of Grit
Comment: There are several learnings from the brick and mortar retail world that apply to digital first brands. Simple concepts of target sell-through price, discounts only when needed to clear stocks, bundles/ deals and limited time offers to generate excitement. Sadly, everyone thinks they're a great tech firm solving complex technical issues, when in reality consumer behaviour hardly changes between physical and digital shopping. Even loyalty is far too strong a word to use. And therefore you see several physical brands moving to rewards systems - collect enough points to offset against future purchases. It appeals to a core human value - greed :)

Headline: Building FlexyPe | Turning Intent into Revenue
Comment:
Everyoneâ€™s busy shouting â€œ50% OFFâ€ like itâ€™s a growth hack. Itâ€™s not, itâ€™s a habit-forming drug.

When you treat a new customer and a loyal one the same way, donâ€™t be surprised when they behave the same way too.

At FlexyPe, we decided to flip that.
- Why give 40% to someone whoâ€™d buy happily at 20%?
- Every shopper is different - your discounts should be too.

Headline: Investment Banking | Private Wealth | Arambh Ventures
Comment:
As a consumer - whenever I see a 50% - 70% discount on anything, the first thought is - this is not a discount. It is a distress sale.

Then the evaluation becomes a matter of quality/ relevance over price discount. More precisely - is this still the right price, even after discount? Or is it better to pay full price for a better/ more relevant product?

I like Sleepy Owl Coffee in this matter. Consistent pricing, and gradual reduction of discounts. Been paying almost 20% more for the last 3-4 months, but still worth the product quality at predictable pricing.

Headline: Co-Founder For Real | Ex-VC | IIT Delhi
Comment:
Discounting short circuits the price vs perceived value of the product gap. 

Keeping sales boosting aside, brands often discount to liquidate aged inventory. This issue can only be mitigated, never eradicated.

The challenge is that brands don't have a separate channel to liquidate aged inventory and hence are forced to deep discount on their stores, website/app, and other marketplaces to unlock cashflow.

What we need is a destinated away from primary channels of sales, which speaks to value-focused audiences hence protecting brand equity among high-intent category consumers that a brand regularly positions to. 

About time the country builds an online factory outlet model.
